_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:      Iowa Double Circle,  Libertyville,IA
Contact:     Fred Filson
Phone:       800-447-4148

1.  Facility Policy.

     The owners, management and employees of Iowa Double Circle (Libertyville) are
     committed to providing a safe workplace free of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia and
     propane.  Health, safety, and environmental compliance are a fundamental part of every employee's
     job.  It is facility protocol to adhere to applicable Federal, State, and local laws and to implement
     appropriate controls to prevent accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia and propane.  If an
     accidental release were to occur, the facility would respond in accordance with its Emergency Action   
     Plan and is prepared to work with local fire department, the Local Emergency Planning Committee
     and other authorities to control and mitigate the release and minimize the impact of the release
     to employees, the environment, and the general public.

2.  Facility Information.

     The primary activity at the facility is the storage and handling of fertilizers for the direct sale to
     farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application.  Anhydrous
     ammonia is stored in two storage tanks of 28,000 gal and 30,000 gal.  These tanks are located
     at the far West of the plant.  Anhydrous ammonia is also stored in five 1450 gal wagons and
     thirty-five 1000 gal wagons.  These wagons are stored next to the storage tanks.  The maximum
     quantity of Anhydrous ammonia would be 439,000 pounds.  Propane is stored in three storage tanks 
     of 18,000 gal, 18,000 gal, and 16,900 gal.  These tanks are located at the far East of the plant.
     The maximum quantity of propane would be 180,200 pounds.  The maximum fill level of each tank
      is 85% of the total tank capacity, which is controlled by a liquid level guage.

3.  Worst-Case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario.

     a.     The worst-case scenario would be the release of the total contents of a storage
              tank released as gas over a period of 10 minutes.

             Anhydrous Ammonia - The maximum quanity released would be 127,500 pounds,
             which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85 percent capacity as
             limited by design standards.  The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to
             200 parts per million, or ppm) is 2.6 miles.

             Propane - The maximum quantity released would be 56,000 pounds.  The distance
             to the end point (point of 1 psi overpressure) is 0.3 miles.

     b.     The alternate release scenario, based on the five-year accident hjistory ( or the most
             likely potential incident), is as follows:

             Anhydrous Ammonia - The alternate release scenario is a release from a break in a
             3 - inch transfer hose followed by release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an
             automatic or manual shut-off intervenes and stops the flow of ammonia.  The
             maximum quantity released would be 69 pounds.  The distance to the endpoint
             (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 0.03 miles.

             Propane - The alternate release from hose rupture caused by a pull-away and
             assumes a 25-foot length of 4-inch transfer hose.  The active mitigation devices
             are assumed to function as designed, limiting the release to the contents of the 
             hose.  The maximum quanitity released would be 69 pounds.  The distance to the
             end point (point of 1 psi overpressure) is 0.03 miles, or 175 feet.




4.  Accidental Release Prevention Program.     
   
     1) Safety Information: The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with app

licable
     Federal and State of Iowa regulations.  All plans and procedures maintained at the facility are
     periodically reviewed by facility management for safety updates and changes.  Material Safety
     Data Sheets, equipment specifications and the codes and standards used to build and operate
     the anhydrous ammonia and propane equipment are maintained at the facility.

     2) Hazard Review: Facility management conducts reviews of the hazards associated with the
     handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia and propane.  The reviews identify the opportunity
     for equipment malfunctions or human errors that could cause an accidental release, the safeguards
     used to control hazards and prevent releases, and the steps used to detect or monitor releases.
     The results of the reviews are documented and problems identified are addressed in a timely manner.

     3) Operating Procedures: The facility maintains written procedures for the handling and storage of
     anhydrous ammonia and propane.  The procedures generally follow the provisions of the Occupational
     Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standard, 29 CFR 1910.111, Staorage and Handling of
     Anhydrous Ammonia.  The ANSI Standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa Administrative
     Code Part 21-Chapter 43-Rule 43.6(200)-Standard for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.
     The applicable standard for propane is NFPA - 58. The written procedures are reviewed by facility
     management on a regular basis and revised as necessary.

     4) Training: All employees at the facility that handle anhydrous ammonia participate in a training
     program.  Training for all employees consists of classroom type instruction (e.g. reading safety
     information, operating procedures, response measures followed by a written test.) and on-the-job
     supervision.  All employees are trained annually.  The training program is reviewed by facility
     management on a regular

basis and revised as necessary.  All Propane employees are sent 
     to State and National Propane Association Training.

     5) Maintenance: The facility maintains written equipment inspection and maintenance procedures.
     Storage and transfer/process equipment inspections are preformed by qualified personnel on
     an annual basis and are documented.  Equipment maintenance procedures follow either instructions
     furnished by the equipment vendors, Federal or State regulations, or Industry Codes.  The written
     procedures are reviewed by facility management on a regular basis and revised as necessary.

     6) Compliance Audits: As required by the RMP rule, compliance audits will be performed at least
     every three (3) years.  The audit will be documented and conducted by a person knowledgeable
     in the safe handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia and propane.  Corrective actions required
     as a result of each compliance audit will be performed and documented.

     7) Incident Investigation: Facility management will investigate each incident that results, or could have
     reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia or propane.  The investigation
     will be performed to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as corrective actions to
     prevent the release from reoccurring.  Investigation reports will be maintained for five years.

5.   Five-Year Accident History.

     There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or propane in the past five
     years that:  have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility;
     nor to our knowledge, have resulted in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in
     place, property damage, or environmental damage.

6.  Emergency Response Program.    

     The facility has:

     a.     a written action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38;
             In the event of an emergency, it is facil

ity protocol to notify the local fire department and
             other emergency responders and request that they respond to the emergency.  Facility
             employees will not respond to accidental releases except for those that are small or incidental,
             can be controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area
             (e.g. shutting a valve),  and do not appear to pose an immediate safety or health hazard.
             This protocol has been discussed with the local fire department and other emergency
             responders and facility has appropriate mechanisms in place to notify the emergency
             responders when there is a need for a response.

     b.     provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community
             right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).  The facility is included
             in the written community emergency response plan.




7.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

     Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are
     performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific
     safety recommendations regarding storage or use of anhydrous ammonia and propane for
     implementation at this time.
